elements.content: A 3-D lithium based metal organic framework Li2(C7H3NO4)·(C3H7NO) [Li2(2,5-PDC)·(DMF), 1; ULMOF-5, UL= ultralight, PDC = pyridinedicarboxylate, space group Pbcn, a = 15.800(3) Å, b = 8.5958(17) Å, c = 18.460(4) Å, V = 2507.1(9) Å3] was synthesized using the solvothermal method and characterized by single crystal and powder X-ray diffraction techniques. Compound 1 contains tetrameric edge and corner sharing lithium polyhedral clusters connected by organic linkers, forming channels along the [001] direction, with coordinated DMF molecules pointing toward each other in these channels. Thermogravimetric analysis shows compound 1 is stable up to 280 °C under N2 atmosphere followed by removal of the coordinated DMF molecules, as evident from the associated weight loss. BET (25.06 m2/g) surface area measurement showed loss of porosity after solvent removal because of a structure change. Solid-state 6Li NMR on the desolvated compound showed the absence of tricoordinated lithium centers, indicating rearrangement of bonds around the lithium center after DMF removal. The desolvated form reverts to the original form upon exposure to DMF, showing dynamic structural behavior.
elements.clean_text: A 3-D lithium based metal organic framework Li2(C7H3NO4)⋅(C3H7NO) [Li2(2,5-PDC)⋅(DMF), 1; ULMOF-5, UL= ultralight, PDC = pyridinedicarboxylate, space group Pbcn, a = 15.800(3) Å, b = 8.5958(17) Å, c = 18.460(4) Å, V = 2507.1(9) Å3] was synthesized using the solvothermal method and characterized by single crystal and powder X-ray diffraction techniques. Compound 1 contains tetrameric edge and corner sharing lithium polyhedral clusters connected by organic linkers, forming channels along the [001] direction, with coordinated DMF molecules pointing toward each other in these channels. Thermogravimetric analysis shows compound 1 is stable up to 280 °C under N2 atmosphere followed by removal of the coordinated DMF molecules, as evident from the associated weight loss. BET (25.06 m2/g) surface area measurement showed loss of porosity after solvent removal because of a structure change. Solid-state 6Li NMR on the desolvated compound showed the absence of tricoordinated lithium centers, indicating rearrangement of bonds around the lithium center after DMF removal. The desolvated form reverts to the original form upon exposure to DMF, showing dynamic structural behavior.

elements.content: A 3-D ultralight metal organic framework (ULMOF) was synthesized using lithium metal as the node and 2,5-pyrdine dicarboxylic acid (2,5-PDC) as the organic linker. DMF molecules coordinated with the lithium centers are pointed toward the channel. The framework is stable up to 280 °C under N2 atmosphere and shows very limited H2 uptake after desolvation due to a structure change. 6Li NMR reveals the absence of a 3-coordinated lithium center after removal of coordinated solvent. The desolvated compound reverts to its original form upon soaking with DMF.
elements.clean_text: A 3-D ultralight metal organic framework (ULMOF) was synthesized using lithium metal as the node and 2,5-pyrdine dicarboxylic acid (2,5-PDC) as the organic linker. DMF molecules coordinated with the lithium centers are pointed toward the channel. The framework is stable up to 280 °C under N2 atmosphere and shows very limited H2 uptake after desolvation due to a structure change. 6Li NMR reveals the absence of a 3-coordinated lithium center after removal of coordinated solvent. The desolvated compound reverts to its original form upon soaking with DMF.

elements.content: Metal organic frameworks (MOFs)−networks formed by arrays of metal centers connected by multifunctional organic ligands−are of intensive current interest due to their potential use in gas storage, separation, catalysis, sensing, and detection. Research in this area aims at tailoring the synthesis by choosing appropriate metal centers and organic linkers to form networks, suitable for desired uses. The work so far in uncovering materials useful for gas storage applications has targeted first row transition metals, which are commonly used due to their well-known coordination preference with polycarboxylate based aromatic ligands. Despite the obvious gravimetric advantages of lightweight metal centers (e.g., lithium, magnesium) for gas storage applications, their use in the construction of open networks is limited so far. Recent theoretical and experimental studies on lithium doped MOFs show enhanced H2 uptake due to strong electrostatic interaction between bare lithium centers and adsorbed H2 molecules. Our strategy is to build frameworks using both these concepts, i.e. a lithium based coordination network with accessible lithium metal sites for gas storage applications.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Metal organic frameworks (MOFs)-networks formed by arrays of metal centers connected by multifunctional organic ligands-are of intensive current interest due to their potential use in gas storage, separation, catalysis, sensing, and detection. Research in this area aims at tailoring the synthesis by choosing appropriate metal centers and organic linkers to form networks, suitable for desired uses. The work so far in uncovering materials useful for gas storage applications has targeted first row transition metals, which are commonly used due to their well-known coordination preference with polycarboxylate based aromatic ligands. Despite the obvious gravimetric advantages of lightweight metal centers (e.g., lithium, magnesium) for gas storage applications, their use in the construction of open networks is limited so far. Recent theoretical and experimental studies on lithium doped MOFs show enhanced H2 uptake due to strong electrostatic interaction between bare lithium centers and adsorbed H2 molecules. Our strategy is to build frameworks using both these concepts, i.e. a lithium based coordination network with accessible lithium metal sites for gas storage applications.

elements.content: The most common way of generating unsaturated metal sites within the framework is to remove coordinated solvent molecules under inert conditions. A lithium-based framework with coordinated solvent molecules would therefore be an interesting precursor to generate a framework with unsaturated Li-sites. A successful gas storage medium based on the strategy outlined above is of course dependent on the ability of the desolvated framework to support permanent porosity. Unfortunately, the removal of coordinated solvent molecules often results in loss of porosity, leading to amorphization or rearrangement of the coordination environment around metal centers.
elements.clean_text: The most common way of generating unsaturated metal sites within the framework is to remove coordinated solvent molecules under inert conditions. A lithium-based framework with coordinated solvent molecules would therefore be an interesting precursor to generate a framework with unsaturated Li-sites. A successful gas storage medium based on the strategy outlined above is of course dependent on the ability of the desolvated framework to support permanent porosity. Unfortunately, the removal of coordinated solvent molecules often results in loss of porosity, leading to amorphization or rearrangement of the coordination environment around metal centers.

elements.content: The recent studies on the Li-doped MOFs and the possibility of producing coordinatively unsaturated Li-sites through desolvation encouraged us to explore the types of networks formed by using lithium metal centers and rigid aromatic ligands. Our study suggests formation of a wide range of networks of diverse topology depending on the synthetic conditions. Herein, we report the solvothermal synthesis, characterization, and structural dynamics of a lithium based 3-D framework, Li2(2,5-PDC) DMF (ULMOF-5, compound 1), produced as part of our ongoing study.
elements.clean_text: The recent studies on the Li-doped MOFs and the possibility of producing coordinatively unsaturated Li-sites through desolvation encouraged us to explore the types of networks formed by using lithium metal centers and rigid aromatic ligands. Our study suggests formation of a wide range of networks of diverse topology depending on the synthetic conditions. Herein, we report the solvothermal synthesis, characterization, and structural dynamics of a lithium based 3-D framework, Li2(2,5-PDC) DMF (ULMOF-5, compound 1), produced as part of our ongoing study.

elements.content: The synthesis of compound 1 was carried out under solvothermal conditions using Teflon-lined 23-mL Parr stainless steel autoclaves. Starting materials include lithium nitrate (LiNO3, 99+%, Acros-Organic), 2,5-pyridinedicarboxylic acid (2,5-PDC, Sigma-Aldrich, 98%), lithium hydroxide (LiOH·H2O, 98%, Alfa-Aesar), N,N-dimethylformamide (C3H7NO, DMF, 99%, Sigma-Aldrich), and ethanol (C2H5OH, 99%, Sigma-Aldrich), and they were used without any further purification.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

Synthesis

The synthesis of compound 1 was carried out under solvothermal conditions using Teflon-lined 23-mL Parr stainless steel autoclaves. Starting materials include lithium nitrate (LiNO3, 99+%, Acros-Organic), 2,5-pyridinedicarboxylic acid (2,5-PDC, Sigma-Aldrich, 98%), lithium hydroxide (LiOH⋅H2O, 98%, Alfa-Aesar), N,N-dimethylformamide (C3H7NO, DMF, 99%, Sigma-Aldrich), and ethanol (C2H5OH, 99%, Sigma-Aldrich), and they were used without any further purification.

elements.content:
Structure 1: Li2(C7H3NO4)·(C3H7NO): ULMOF-5.

A mixture of 0.005 mol of 2,5-PDC (0.85 g), 0.005 mol of LiNO3 (0.345 g), and 0.0005 mol of LiOH·H2O (0.021 g) was dissolved in 15 g of DMF [molar ratio of metal salt/ligand/solvent = 1:1:41]. The resultant gel was stirred for 4 h and heated at 180 °C for 5 days. The product was obtained as needle shaped colorless crystals (Yield: 50% based on Li) from a filtrate rinsed with DMF.
elements.clean_text:
Structure 1: Li2(C7H3NO4)⋅(C3H7NO): ULMOF-5.

A mixture of 0.005 mol of 2,5-PDC (0.85 g), 0.005 mol of LiNO3 (0.345 g), and 0.0005 mol of LiOH⋅H2O (0.021 g) was dissolved in 15 g of DMF [molar ratio of metal salt/ligand/solvent = 1:1:41]. The resultant gel was stirred for 4 h and heated at 180 °C for 5 days. The product was obtained as needle shaped colorless crystals (Yield: 50% based on Li) from a filtrate rinsed with DMF.

elements.content: A suitable crystal of compound 1 was selected from the bulk sample and was mounted pn a glass fiber using epoxy. Reflections were collected using a Bruker four circle P4 single crystal diffractometer equipped with a SMART 1K CCD detector at room temperature (298 K) using Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å) and φ and ω scans. The raw intensity data were collected and integrated with the software packages SMART and SAINT. An empirical absorption correction was applied using SADABS. The crystal structure was solved using direct methods (SHELXS). Oxygen atoms were located first, followed by the determination of other atoms positions (C, N, Li) from the Fourier difference map. All non-hydrogen atoms were refined anisotropically. Hydrogen atoms were added to the pyridine rings using geometrical constraints (HFIX command).
elements.clean_text:
X-ray Crystallography

A suitable crystal of compound 1 was selected from the bulk sample and was mounted pn a glass fiber using epoxy. Reflections were collected using a Bruker four circle P4 single crystal diffractometer equipped with a SMART 1K CCD detector at room temperature (298 K) using Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å) and φ and ω scans. The raw intensity data were collected and integrated with the software packages SMART and SAINT. An empirical absorption correction was applied using SADABS. The crystal structure was solved using direct methods (SHELXS). Oxygen atoms were located first, followed by the determination of other atoms positions (C, N, Li) from the Fourier difference map. All non-hydrogen atoms were refined anisotropically. Hydrogen atoms were added to the pyridine rings using geometrical constraints (HFIX command).

elements.content: Bulk sample identification and phase purity were determined using powder X-ray diffraction. The data were collected using a Scintag Pad-X diffractometer equipped with Cu Kα radiation (λ = 1.54178 Å) within an angular range of 5° ≤ 2θ ≤ 40°, a step size 0.02°, and a counting time of 1 s/step. The powder patterns so collected were consistent with the powder patterns simulated based on the single crystal data (Figure ).
elements.clean_text: Bulk sample identification and phase purity were determined using powder X-ray diffraction. The data were collected using a Scintag Pad-X diffractometer equipped with Cu Kα radiation (λ = 1.54178 Å) within an angular range of 5° ≤ 2θ ≤ 40°, a step size 0.02°, and a counting time of 1 s/step. The powder patterns so collected were consistent with the powder patterns simulated based on the single crystal data (Figure ).

elements.content:
Combined TGA-DSC data were collected using a Netzsch 449C Jupiter instrument. The samples were heated from room temperature to 700 °C under a N2 atmosphere with a heating rate of 5 °C/min (Figure ).

BET Analysis

The surface area measurement of compound 1 was carried out using a Quantachrome Nova 2200e surface area analyzer. To avoid structural collapse of the material due to rapid degassing, the sample was first evacuated at room temperature for 1 h and then the temperature was increased at the rate of 3 °C/min to 295 °C. After a 12-h degassing period, the sample was weighed to confirm the complete removal of both free and coordinated DMF molecules (33% of the starting weight) and analyzed. The surface area was calculated from a linear 5-point BET plot acquired from analysis at liquid N2 temperature (77 K) using N2 adsorbate gas.
elements.clean_text:
Combined TGA-DSC data were collected using a Netzsch 449C Jupiter instrument. The samples were heated from room temperature to 700 °C under a N2 atmosphere with a heating rate of 5 °C/min (Figure ).

BET Analysis

The surface area measurement of compound 1 was carried out using a Quantachrome Nova 2200e surface area analyzer. To avoid structural collapse of the material due to rapid degassing, the sample was first evacuated at room temperature for 1 h and then the temperature was increased at the rate of 3 °C/min to 295 °C. After a 12-h degassing period, the sample was weighed to confirm the complete removal of both free and coordinated DMF molecules (33% of the starting weight) and analyzed. The surface area was calculated from a linear 5-point BET plot acquired from analysis at liquid N2 temperature (77 K) using N2 adsorbate gas.

elements.content: Solid-state 6Li single-pulse MAS NMR spectra were collected on a 400 MHz Varian Inova spectrometer (9.4 T), with Larmor frequencies of 58.9 MHz. Spectra were collected using Varian/Chemagnetics T3-type probe samples contained in 3.2 mm (o.d.) normal wall ZrO2 rotors with a spinning speed of 15 kHz. A 3 μs rf pulse length was chosen based on a calibrated 8.5 μs 90° pulse by using the LiCl solution standard. The pulse delay was optimized as 200 s, and ca. 300 scans were collected for each spectrum to obtain a decent signal-to-noise ratio. The 6Li chemical shifts (δiso,Li) are reported relative to an external 1 M LiCl solution set to δiso,Li = 0 ppm.
elements.clean_text:
6Li Solid State NMR

Solid-state 6Li single-pulse MAS NMR spectra were collected on a 400 MHz Varian Inova spectrometer (9.4 T), with Larmor frequencies of 58.9 MHz. Spectra were collected using Varian/Chemagnetics T3-type probe samples contained in 3.2 mm (o.d.) normal wall ZrO2 rotors with a spinning speed of 15 kHz. A 3 μs rf pulse length was chosen based on a calibrated 8.5 μs 90° pulse by using the LiCl solution standard. The pulse delay was optimized as 200 s, and ca. 300 scans were collected for each spectrum to obtain a decent signal-to-noise ratio. The 6Li chemical shifts (δiso,Li) are reported relative to an external 1 M LiCl solution set to δiso,Li = 0 ppm.

elements.content: Compound 1 consists of tetrameric corner and edge sharing lithium tetrahedral clusters, connected by the organic linkers to form a 3-D network (Figure ). Its crstallographic data are presented in Table . The organic linker (2,5-PDC), one coordinated DMF molecule, and two crystallographically independent lithium metal centers (Li1 and Li2) are present in the asymmetric unit of compound 1 (Figure ). Each lithium center is in distorted tetrahedral coordination, with Li1 coordinated to three carboxylate oxygen atoms (O1, O2, O3) and one DMF oxygen (O1M) at distances between 1.892(2) Å and 1.976(3) Å () and Li2 coordinated to three carboxylate oxygen atoms (O1, O4) and one pyridyl nitrogen atom (N1) at distances between 1.901(2) Å and 2.082(3) Å (). These Li-coordination geometries are consistent with recently reported lithium based frameworks. Further details of coordination geometries are summarized in Table . The bond valence sums of Li1 and Li2 are calculated as 1.07 and 1.16 v.u. (v.u. = valence unit), close to the expected value of 1.
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussions

Structural Description of 1, Li2(2,5-PDC)⋅(DMF), ULMOF-5, Compound 1 

Compound 1 consists of tetrameric corner and edge sharing lithium tetrahedral clusters, connected by the organic linkers to form a 3-D network (Figure ). Its crstallographic data are presented in Table . The organic linker (2,5-PDC), one coordinated DMF molecule, and two crystallographically independent lithium metal centers (Li1 and Li2) are present in the asymmetric unit of compound 1 (Figure ). Each lithium center is in distorted tetrahedral coordination, with Li1 coordinated to three carboxylate oxygen atoms (O1, O2, O3) and one DMF oxygen (O1M) at distances between 1.892(2) Å and 1.976(3) Å () and Li2 coordinated to three carboxylate oxygen atoms (O1, O4) and one pyridyl nitrogen atom (N1) at distances between 1.901(2) Å and 2.082(3) Å (). These Li-coordination geometries are consistent with recently reported lithium based frameworks. Further details of coordination geometries are summarized in Table . The bond valence sums of Li1 and Li2 are calculated as 1.07 and 1.16 v.u. (v.u. = valence unit), close to the expected value of 1.

elements.content: View of the 3-D layers of ULMOF-5 from the [001] direction.
elements.clean_text: 1  View of the 3-D layers of ULMOF-5 from the [001] direction.

elements.content: Ellipsoidal plot of the asymmetric unit of ULMOF-5. Ellipsoids are shown at the 50% probability level. Hydrogen atoms have been omitted for clarity. Symmetry related atoms are shown to complete the coordination sphere of the lithium center. Symmetry operators: (i) x, y, z; (ii) −x + 1/2, −y + 1/2, z + 1/2; (iii) −x, y, −z + 1/2.
elements.clean_text: 2  Ellipsoidal plot of the asymmetric unit of ULMOF-5. Ellipsoids are shown at the 50% probability level. Hydrogen atoms have been omitted for clarity. Symmetry related atoms are shown to complete the coordination sphere of the lithium center. Symmetry operators: (i) x, y, z; (ii) -x + 1/2, -y + 1/2, z + 1/2; (iii) -x, y, -z + 1/2.

Symmetry codes: (1) −x, y, −z + 1/2; (2) −x, −y + 1, −z + 1.

The tetrameric lithium polyhedral cluster serves as the backbone of compound 1. An edge sharing dimer of Li2 tetrahedra connected by corner sharing Li1 tetrahedra on both sides composes the tetramer. The average distance between each Li2 center within the dimer is 2.66 Å, while the distance between each corner sharing lithium center (Li1 and Li2) is on average 3.07 Å. Each of these tetrameric chains is joined by the carboxylate groups of the organic linkers along the [001] direction to form a quasi 1-D chain of lithium tetrahedra (Figure ). The DMF molecules are connected with the Li1 center at one vertex of the tetrahedra.
elements.clean_text: The tetrameric lithium polyhedral cluster serves as the backbone of compound 1. An edge sharing dimer of Li2 tetrahedra connected by corner sharing Li1 tetrahedra on both sides composes the tetramer. The average distance between each Li2 center within the dimer is 2.66 Å, while the distance between each corner sharing lithium center (Li1 and Li2) is on average 3.07 Å. Each of these tetrameric chains is joined by the carboxylate groups of the organic linkers along the [001] direction to form a quasi 1-D chain of lithium tetrahedra (Figure ). The DMF molecules are connected with the Li1 center at one vertex of the tetrahedra.

elements.content: Arrangement of lithium tetrahedra from the [100] direction (DMF molecules are shown to be connected with the Li1 center).
elements.clean_text: 3  Arrangement of lithium tetrahedra from the [100] direction (DMF molecules are shown to be connected with the Li1 center).

elements.content: Each organic linker (2,5-PDC) is associated with a total of six lithium metal centers. Among the four carboxylate oxygens, only O4 and O1 are connected with two lithium centers, while the other two are connected with one lithium center each (). Compound 1 forms a 3-D channel along the [001] direction. The coordinated DMF molecules are directed toward each other within the channel (Figure ). Four quasi 1-D lithium tetrahedral chains surround each channel. The channels along the [001] direction have dimensions 4.1 Å × 11.4 Å, estimated using van der Waals radii.
elements.clean_text: Each organic linker (2,5-PDC) is associated with a total of six lithium metal centers. Among the four carboxylate oxygens, only O4 and O1 are connected with two lithium centers, while the other two are connected with one lithium center each (). Compound 1 forms a 3-D channel along the [001] direction. The coordinated DMF molecules are directed toward each other within the channel (Figure ). Four quasi 1-D lithium tetrahedral chains surround each channel. The channels along the [001] direction have dimensions 4.1 Å × 11.4 Å, estimated using van der Waals radii.

elements.content: The coordination geometry of the metal centers and the functionality of the organic linkers influence the formation of multidimensional coordination polymers. The individual properties of the metal center and the organic linker combine to determine the bulk property of the overall network. Lithium is generally tetrahedrally coordinated with carboxylate oxygens; thus, the orientation of the functional groups in the organic linker plays a vital role in determining the overall framework topology. Two different types of coordination environment are present in compound 1, arising due to the position of the pyridyl nitrogen with respect to the carboxylate groups in the linker. The organic linker acts as a bidented chelating agent to the Li2 metal center through pyridyl nitrogen (N1) and carboxylate oxygen (O1) while no such chelating effect is present for Li1. The chelating effect is responsible for the higher bond valence sum (1.16 v.u.) for Li2. Li1, on the other hand, experiences a flexible coordination environment with a solvent molecule occupying its coordination sphere.
elements.clean_text:
Discussions

The coordination geometry of the metal centers and the functionality of the organic linkers influence the formation of multidimensional coordination polymers. The individual properties of the metal center and the organic linker combine to determine the bulk property of the overall network. Lithium is generally tetrahedrally coordinated with carboxylate oxygens; thus, the orientation of the functional groups in the organic linker plays a vital role in determining the overall framework topology. Two different types of coordination environment are present in compound 1, arising due to the position of the pyridyl nitrogen with respect to the carboxylate groups in the linker. The organic linker acts as a bidented chelating agent to the Li2 metal center through pyridyl nitrogen (N1) and carboxylate oxygen (O1) while no such chelating effect is present for Li1. The chelating effect is responsible for the higher bond valence sum (1.16 v.u.) for Li2. Li1, on the other hand, experiences a flexible coordination environment with a solvent molecule occupying its coordination sphere.

elements.content: The combined TGA-DSC study (Figure ) showed the removal of the coordinated DMF molecule (calculated, 28.9%; observed, 29.4%) at 280 °C under a N2 atmosphere. The requirement of high temperature to remove the coordinated solvent molecule indicates a strong bonding interaction. Compound 1 possesses a theoretical 37% (400 Å3) void space after removal of coordinated DMF molecules from the Li1 center. The removal of coordinated DMF molecules from the channel thus could generate unsaturated lithium sites, the accessibility of which depends on the retention of the pore volume. The surface area of the desolvated compound 1 shows a BET surface area of 25.06 m2/g. The successive H2 and CO2 adsorption too shows very limited uptake (0.1 wt %) at 77 K and 1 atm pressure (). The low surface area and limited H2 uptake indicate the destruction of the channel after removal of coordinated DMF molecules. Compound 1 forms an unidentified polycrystalline phase (compound 1a) upon desolvation, as evident from the PXRD pattern (Figure ).
elements.clean_text: The combined TGA-DSC study (Figure ) showed the removal of the coordinated DMF molecule (calculated, 28.9%; observed, 29.4%) at 280 °C under a N2 atmosphere. The requirement of high temperature to remove the coordinated solvent molecule indicates a strong bonding interaction. Compound 1 possesses a theoretical 37% (400 Å3) void space after removal of coordinated DMF molecules from the Li1 center. The removal of coordinated DMF molecules from the channel thus could generate unsaturated lithium sites, the accessibility of which depends on the retention of the pore volume. The surface area of the desolvated compound 1 shows a BET surface area of 25.06 m2/g. The successive H2 and CO2 adsorption too shows very limited uptake (0.1 wt %) at 77 K and 1 atm pressure (). The low surface area and limited H2 uptake indicate the destruction of the channel after removal of coordinated DMF molecules. Compound 1 forms an unidentified polycrystalline phase (compound 1a) upon desolvation, as evident from the PXRD pattern (Figure ).

elements.content: Combined TGA-DSC plot of ULMOF-5. The blue line represents TGA plot of ULMOF-5 while the red line shows the DSC signal associated with it.
elements.clean_text: 4  Combined TGA-DSC plot of ULMOF-5. The blue line represents TGA plot of ULMOF-5 while the red line shows the DSC signal associated with it.

elements.content: The local structures of lithium centers in compounds 1 and 1a were investigated by 6Li solid state NMR. Two distinct peaks were observed for compound 1 at chemical shifts of 0.79 and 1.47 ppm, respectively (Figure ). These chemical shifts indicate a four-coordination Li environment, consistent with the structure obtained from single crystal X-diffraction data. Compound 1a also showed two different peaks in 6Li NMR, but with two different chemical shifts at 0.81 and 0.17 ppm, respectively. The difference in chemical shifts confirms the changes in structure as observed in powder XRD data. The small values of chemical shits do not support the three-coordination Li environment. The absence of a three coordinated Li center after removal of DMF suggests rearrangement of bonding around the lithium site (Li1). The TGA-DSC performed on compound 1a () proved the absence of any DMF and adsorbed moisture in it (Figure ).
elements.clean_text: The local structures of lithium centers in compounds 1 and 1a were investigated by 6Li solid state NMR. Two distinct peaks were observed for compound 1 at chemical shifts of 0.79 and 1.47 ppm, respectively (Figure ). These chemical shifts indicate a four-coordination Li environment, consistent with the structure obtained from single crystal X-diffraction data. Compound 1a also showed two different peaks in 6Li NMR, but with two different chemical shifts at 0.81 and 0.17 ppm, respectively. The difference in chemical shifts confirms the changes in structure as observed in powder XRD data. The small values of chemical shits do not support the three-coordination Li environment. The absence of a three coordinated Li center after removal of DMF suggests rearrangement of bonding around the lithium site (Li1). The TGA-DSC performed on compound 1a () proved the absence of any DMF and adsorbed moisture in it (Figure ).

elements.content: 6Li single pulse NMR spectra for samples a and b, collected with a spinning rate of 15 kHz, a pulse delay of 200 s, and ca. 300 scans each.
elements.clean_text: 5   6Li single pulse NMR spectra for samples a and b, collected with a spinning rate of 15 kHz, a pulse delay of 200 s, and ca. 300 scans each.

elements.content: The nature of lithium coordination in both compounds 1 and 1a was further investigated by solvent exchange studies. Both compounds 1 and 1a are soluble in water and methanol. Compounds 1 and 1a do not show any structural change under common organic solvents such as ethanol, acetonitrile, acetone, ethyl acetate, and DCM, while, interestingly, compound 1a reverts to the original structure upon soaking with DMF, as evident by PXRD (Figure ). The parent structure can be regenerated by soaking the desolvated form in the coordination solvent on rare occasions, depending on the dynamic nature of the framework structure. The observation of a similar phenomenon in this case confirms the presence of “dynamic structural behavior” in the lithium-based framework, emphasizing the flexibility of the coordination environment around the Li1 center and the favorable interaction of the lithium center and DMF molecules.
elements.clean_text: The nature of lithium coordination in both compounds 1 and 1a was further investigated by solvent exchange studies. Both compounds 1 and 1a are soluble in water and methanol. Compounds 1 and 1a do not show any structural change under common organic solvents such as ethanol, acetonitrile, acetone, ethyl acetate, and DCM, while, interestingly, compound 1a reverts to the original structure upon soaking with DMF, as evident by PXRD (Figure ). The parent structure can be regenerated by soaking the desolvated form in the coordination solvent on rare occasions, depending on the dynamic nature of the framework structure. The observation of a similar phenomenon in this case confirms the presence of "dynamic structural behavior" in the lithium-based framework, emphasizing the flexibility of the coordination environment around the Li1 center and the favorable interaction of the lithium center and DMF molecules.

elements.content: PXRD pattern of ULMOF-5 after desolvation and soaking with DMF.
elements.clean_text: 6  PXRD pattern of ULMOF-5 after desolvation and soaking with DMF.

elements.content: A lithium based 3-D framework was synthesized using 2,5-PDC (ULMOF-5, compound 1) as the organic linker. Compound 1 consists of tetrameric lithium polyhedral clusters connected by organic linears. Coordinated DMF molecules are present in the channel of the structure. They undergo structural change after desolvation, as evident from the PXRD. BET and very low H2 uptake confirm the loss of porosity in the desolvated structure. Solid state Li NMR shows structural rearrangement around the lithium center after solvent removal. The flexibility of lithium coordination is evident, as compound 1 is regenerated from its desolvated form upon soaking with DMF. The detailed structural and thermal characterization of ULMOF-5 (compound 1) enables us to understand the chemical nature of these potentially interesting new classes of MOFs. We are currently using ligands of more diverse and robust nature to explore the chemistry of networks based on ultralight metals.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusion

A lithium based 3-D framework was synthesized using 2,5-PDC (ULMOF-5, compound 1) as the organic linker. Compound 1 consists of tetrameric lithium polyhedral clusters connected by organic linears. Coordinated DMF molecules are present in the channel of the structure. They undergo structural change after desolvation, as evident from the PXRD. BET and very low H2 uptake confirm the loss of porosity in the desolvated structure. Solid state Li NMR shows structural rearrangement around the lithium center after solvent removal. The flexibility of lithium coordination is evident, as compound 1 is regenerated from its desolvated form upon soaking with DMF. The detailed structural and thermal characterization of ULMOF-5 (compound 1) enables us to understand the chemical nature of these potentially interesting new classes of MOFs. We are currently using ligands of more diverse and robust nature to explore the chemistry of networks based on ultralight metals.

elements.content:

cln_elements.content:
Structure 1: Li2(C7H3NO4)·(C3H7NO): ULMOF-5.

A mixture of 0.005 mol of 2,5-PDC (0.85 g), 0.005 mol of LiNO3 (0.345 g), and 0.0005 mol of LiOH·H2O (0.021 g) was dissolved in 15 g of DMF [molar ratio of metal salt/ligand/solvent = 1:1:41]. The resultant gel was stirred for 4 h and heated at 180 °C for 5 days. The product was obtained as needle shaped colorless crystals (Yield: 50% based on Li) from a filtrate rinsed with DMF.
cln_elements.clean_text:
Structure 1: Li2(C7H3NO4)⋅(C3H7NO): ULMOF-5.

A mixture of 0.005 mol of 2,5-PDC (0.85 g), 0.005 mol of LiNO3 (0.345 g), and 0.0005 mol of LiOH⋅H2O (0.021 g) was dissolved in 15 g of DMF [molar ratio of metal salt/ligand/solvent = 1:1:41]. The resultant gel was stirred for 4 h and heated at 180 °C for 5 days. The product was obtained as needle shaped colorless crystals (Yield: 50% based on Li) from a filtrate rinsed with DMF.

cln_elements.content:
A 3-D lithium based metal organic framework Li2(C7H3NO4)·(C3H7NO) [Li2(2,5-PDC)·(DMF), 1; ULMOF-5, UL= ultralight, PDC = pyridinedicarboxylate, space group Pbcn, a = 15.800(3) Å, b = 8.5958(17) Å, c = 18.460(4) Å, V = 2507.1(9) Å3] was synthesized using the solvothermal method and characterized by single crystal and powder X-ray diffraction techniques. Compound 1 contains tetrameric edge and corner sharing lithium polyhedral clusters connected by organic linkers, forming channels along the [001] direction, with coordinated DMF molecules pointing toward each other in these channels. Thermogravimetric analysis shows compound 1 is stable up to 280 °C under N2 atmosphere followed by removal of the coordinated DMF molecules, as evident from the associated weight loss. BET (25.06 m2/g) surface area measurement showed loss of porosity after solvent removal because of a structure change. Solid-state 6Li NMR on the desolvated compound showed the absence of tricoordinated lithium centers, indicating rearrangement of bonds around the lithium center after DMF removal. The desolvated form reverts to the original form upon exposure to DMF, showing dynamic structural behavior.

The combined TGA-DSC study (Figure ) showed the removal of the coordinated DMF molecule (calculated, 28.9%; observed, 29.4%) at 280 °C under a N2 atmosphere. The requirement of high temperature to remove the coordinated solvent molecule indicates a strong bonding interaction. Compound 1 possesses a theoretical 37% (400 Å3) void space after removal of coordinated DMF molecules from the Li1 center. The removal of coordinated DMF molecules from the channel thus could generate unsaturated lithium sites, the accessibility of which depends on the retention of the pore volume. The surface area of the desolvated compound 1 shows a BET surface area of 25.06 m2/g. The successive H2 and CO2 adsorption too shows very limited uptake (0.1 wt %) at 77 K and 1 atm pressure (). The low surface area and limited H2 uptake indicate the destruction of the channel after removal of coordinated DMF molecules. Compound 1 forms an unidentified polycrystalline phase (compound 1a) upon desolvation, as evident from the PXRD pattern (Figure ).

Solid-state 6Li NMR on the desolvated compound showed the absence of tricoordinated lithium centers, indicating rearrangement of bonds around the lithium center after DMF removal.
